On media bias:

I don't think we can dictate our opinions based on something we hear on cable networks. Additionally, it's a real shame that so much of our public opinion is based on a tweet or facebook post. It's upon ourselves to dig deeper and seek out unbiased information.

1256022594052149251.text:
Are there Utah hotspots? 

Yes, there's a hotspot in North Orem right now. When this happens, the state develops a "strike team" in the sense of going in and figuring out what's happening in a particular neighborhood, do some mobile testing, etc.

1256022127578357760.text:
What should businesses do if they haven't received aid?

Learn about every opportunity to get some immediate financing: the EIDL (you can get a grant of $10K upfront) Paycheck Protection Program, the CARES Act (defer payroll/employer side roll taxes, or carry back taxes)

1256020865009016833.text:
Q: How can we improve "school at home" both now and after?

A: Transitioning to a heavier technology emphasis with online learning-- and improving access to internet. 

Check out my rural broadband bill below ⤵️
https://t.co/gZ9iA6gKFA

1256019613135056896.text:
Q: What will the third wave of legislation include? 

A: We hope to include things that won't add to the national debt, such as banking regulations, that can provide resources for businesses but won't add to the deficit.

1256017114353336325.text:
Q: Do masks really work and why do they matter?

A: Masks cut down the transmission of the disease. We'd like to create a culture in Utah where wearing a mask is a responsible, civic token of helping your neighbors and helping yourself.

1256016419071950851.text:
Q: What's the benefit of quarantining the community vs just those in high risk? 

A: If everyone were exposed, many more get sick and we'd eclipse our healthcare capacity. This gave us more space to get ahold of PPE (masks and gowns).

Q: Are there enough tests in Utah?

A: Right now, Utah has the capacity to test anyone with symptoms consistent with COVID19. You can and should be tested.

1248409544310419457.text:
Q: Why are medical masks so hard to come by?

A: The supply doesn't meet the demand. We were not prepared from a supply chain standpoint & now the entire world needs them. 

🚨The @CDCgov & @GovHerbert recommend cloth masks for the public; N95 masks are for medical professionals.

1248407804651515904.text:
Q: Will the warmer weather bring #COVID19 relief?

A: No data to support either way. Influenza is seasonal in some areas but constant in tropical regions. Just because it's warming up doesn't mean we'll see relief. This is a novel virus-- we don't know how it'll be affected.

1243359132918222850.text:
Q: Could those who test negative go back to work to help the economy?

A: No because testing negative means you don't have the virus that day, not that you're immune. There's no choice between the economy or lives: if we let people die, the economy is destroyed for a lot longer.

1243358416707305472.text:
Q: How is this different from SARS?

A: SARS was lethal but didn’t spread with the same efficacy. COVID19 is spread more easily, by coughing, sneezing and droplets, plus 80% with this virus are walking around with a mild illness able to spread it unknowingly.

1243357981237841920.text:
Q: Could parts of the country start moving again? Will normal life return all at once? 

A: Depends on us. Each city/state has the power to control the scope with social distancing. We're pretty well ahead of the curve in Utah for preventing/slowing the spread- let's stick w/it!

1243356100553928705.text:
Q: Why do we social distance? Why not carry about our normal lives?

A: If we let the disease move unchecked, we'll have far too many cases than hospitals can handle.

By keeping the wave down, we have time to develop drugs to treat this and eventually an effective vaccine.

1093162892311056384.text: Unleashing the power of 5G technology will have lasting, positive impacts on the energy, healthcare, public safety, and transportation sectors—to only name a few. In a nutshell, 5G creates better efficiency, reduction in failures, improved performance, and new functionality.

1093150077781184515.text: We have to remember to keep #5G nonpartisan. Right when it becomes owned by a party, it loses.

1093149749954400256.text: My district includes a wide spectrum of Silicon Slopes and rural areas. Last Congress I introduced the AIRWAVES Act, which encourages rural wireless deployment—critical for rural parts of America like my Congressional District in Southeast Utah.

1093149340326133760.text: 5G means jobs. 5G deployment is projected to create nearly 1,100 jobs, $180 million in new GDP, $96 million in new network investment, and about $70 million in Smart City benefits—and that is just in the City of Provo alone.

1087910038335877120.text: On Title IV changes: “We must do everything we can to protect men and women who are victims of sexually assault. If we’re erring, we need to be erring on the side of the victims.”

1087909266047016961.text: "I think it’s important that we quickly resolve that. The economy is healthy and it’s absorbing these problems, but both of these things introduce uncertainty into the market place, which is what we’re seeing in the stock market.” (2/2)

1087908986546999297.text: On the economy: "Utah is resilient, but the economy in the nation is more fragile. Watching the tariffs and the trade war going on; I'm actually more concerned about that impact on the economy than the shutdown." (1/2)

1087906443494391808.text: On unpaid, furloughed government workers: “I walked through TSA this morning and I was embarrassed. It’s not a good situation in any way, shape, or form— and that’s why I’m here, working with my colleagues, and searching for the answer myself that ends this."

1087904781136478208.text: On the Mueller investigation: "Those that do or do not support the President should want this investigation to be carried through. It’s in our nation’s best interest to be resolved." (2/2)

1087904658142740482.text: On the Mueller investigation: "I am waiting, with great anticipation, for Mueller to finish the investigation & give us the facts. The reality is, we have a faction of the information at our fingertips." (1/2)

1087903631268040706.text: On the shutdown: “You can blame the President all you want, but this is Congress’ fault. We wouldn’t be here if we’d done our job and funded the government. At the end of the day, Congress has to look in the mirror and say, ‘We own this. This is our fault.’”

1087903144204558338.text: "Right now, we don’t have the resources at the border. If you'll remember when 7,000 people showed up, we simply could not process them because we hadn’t invested in our border. We’ve got to put the resources there." (2/2)

1087902801412403200.text: On asylum: “People have been asking for a long time for the ability to seek asylum in their own country, so they don’t have to make the dangerous journey up to the border. This would be a good thing." (1/2)

1087901800521445376.text: On opioids: "In Utah we lead the country in a statistic we should not be proud of: the highest rate of opioid addictions in pregnant women. That's why I introduced the POPPY study act- to find alternatives we have to pain and treatments." MORE: https://t.co/URLokpss94

1087900321538629632.text: On a wall: “Judges, facilities, boots on the ground, technology, all of these have great bipartisan support. Until recently, some type of barrier did have bipartisan support as well. The answer is far broader than a wall. But we as a county must be willing to invest in security."

1087897779358363649.text: Here's the Deseret News op-ed the Congressman published this past weekend: https://t.co/8P1Czz1rtj

1087897483387289601.text: Curtis on the shutdown: “So far in the shutdown, the different sides have clung to different positions w/o inching over. This puts us in ‘winner takes all’ philosophy. ‘Unless I get my way, I’m not conceding.’ This will never solve anything; there’s got to be some give & take."

1080949270184742912.text: The American people expect Congress to do its most basic job: pass a budget and fund the government. If we can’t, then we shouldn’t get paid. Today I introduced H.R. 26, the "No Work, No Pay Act of 2019." My bill would prohibit Congress from being paid during government shutdowns
